content.definition: A system which converts data into Information.

content.description: In this type of system all processes are done manually.

content.title: Investigation and Analysis
content.details: Complete investigation of the existing manual system or the computer-based system. Identify user needs.

methods_of_gathering_information.name: Observation
methods_of_gathering_information.desc: Observing the existing system working. E.g., Observing issuing of books in a library.

methods_of_gathering_information.name: Interviews
methods_of_gathering_information.desc: Meeting staff to discuss matters. E.g., Meeting the librarian.

methods_of_gathering_information.name: Questionnaires
methods_of_gathering_information.desc: Using questionnaires to gather requirements from a large number of users.

methods_of_gathering_information.name: Document sample collection
methods_of_gathering_information.desc: Collecting forms and reports used in the existing system.

methods_of_gathering_information.name: Prototyping
methods_of_gathering_information.desc: Developing a model of the proposed system to demonstrate for feedback.

content.title: Designing the solution
content.details: Creating a blueprint of the new system.
activities: Deciding on required hardware and software

content.title: Coding of the solution
content.details: Writing the program code using a programming language. Objective is to ensure correctness, readability, and portability.

content.title: Testing and debugging
content.details: Resolving errors found in the code.

types_of_testing.name: Unit Testing
types_of_testing.desc: Testing each unit independently. E.g., Testing Accounts branch vs Establishment branch.

types_of_testing.name: Integration Testing
types_of_testing.desc: Combining tested units and testing them together.

types_of_testing.name: System Testing
types_of_testing.desc: Testing the complete system for given inputs and outputs.

types_of_testing.name: Acceptance Testing
types_of_testing.desc: Testing carried out with the users at the final stage to get approval.

approaches.name: Direct deployment
approaches.desc: Terminating the existing system and starting the new one immediately.
approaches.example: Installing new library management software and stopping the manual system.

approaches.name: Parallel deployment
approaches.desc: Using both the existing and new systems together for a period until the new system is stable.
approaches.example: Using new library software alongside the manual system.

approaches.name: Pilot deployment
approaches.desc: Using the new system in a selected area/branch.
approaches.example: Installing system in one district library first.

approaches.name: Phased deployment
approaches.desc: Introducing the system module by module or branch by branch.
approaches.example: Introducing system in the Accounts branch first, then Establishment.

content.title: Maintenance of the system
content.details: Ensuring the system continues to function correctly after installation. Includes correcting bugs, developing new features, and improving performance.

content.name: Waterfall Model
content.description: Linear development where one stage must be completed before the next begins.
features: Complete one stage before going to the next.
Limitation: If user requirements are unclear, the resulting system may differ from what the user wants.

content.name: Iterative Incremental Model
content.description: Developing one small component at a time in an iterative fashion.
features: Developers can use knowledge gained in earlier iterations.
User feedback can be incorporated easily.
System grows larger incrementally until completion.

content.text: Compare and contrast Waterfall Life Cycle model with iterative incremental life cycle model.

sections.title: Summary
content: A system is a collection of different components that usually interconnected towards a common objective.
Any system consists of three basic components namely input, process and output.
Information systems transform data into information.
Information systems can be divided into Manual Information Systems and Computer based Information Systems.
Manual Information Systems does not use computers and performs tasks using human.
Computer based Information Systems use a computer to transform data into information.
Information systems are developed by using the system development life cycle.

The system development life cycle consists of: 1. Investigation and Analysis, 2. Designing Solution, 3. Coding of Solution, 4. Testing and Debugging, 5. Deployment of System, 6. Maintenance of System.
The waterfall life cycle model and iterative incremental models are examples for system development life cycles.
